Posts.Content: DaughterMom wrote: I am so annoyed with my mother's dr. today.  Sorry if this sounds like a rant from the get go. Mom's lower back pain has been more evident over the last few days.  She is taking a 12 hour slow release pain killer, and 4mg hydromorphone for breakout pain.  The prescriptions says take 1 pill 3 times a day, this does not seem to work anymore.  She took a pill at 10:30 this AM, but by 12:30, the pain was still there.  We turned on the heating pad, and I called Kevin the pharmacist (he is so sweet, and knows about mom's condition) to see if she could take another pill, even though it was still early.  My gut feeling was that my mom could take a pill, but she is a "nervous nelly" and wanted to hear from a professional.  Kevin the pharmacist was not in, and the other pharmacist said she should WAIT, (in my opinion, wrong answer) and should only take one every 6 hours!  She also said mom could be building a resistance to the hydromophone and should get her dr. to increase the prescription.  Augh.  I called her doctor next, and I was amazed I even got to speak to her, I said "Mom's pain meds are not working", she said "I'll increase the prescripton"  I said" Thank-you" I went on to explain our current situation, when all of a sudden the phone started beeping at me....she hung up!  OMG!  I was furious!!!! My mother needed to hear from a trained professional that she was not over-dosing herself by taking a pain med too early!!  Her doctor recently won an award to outstanding community service, my god, she could not even take a minute to hear me out!!  So much for serving the community. That's my rant. BUT, if anyone is taking hydromorphone 4mg, how often do you take it?  I also realized that mom was delaying her 12hr pill if she just recently took a breakout or what we call an "in-between" pill.  I told her to take her 12 hr. pill at precisely 12hrs apart, I suggested 8am and 8pm, regardless of when she took an inbetween pill. Hopefully it was good advice?  I will be reminding her from now on. I think I will pay a visit to Kevin the pharmacist.   I have no idea if her dr. will even remember to increase the dosage.  I have no faith in that dr. anymore.   Hope is the thing with feathers, That perches in the soul, And sings the tune without the words, And never stops at all. -Emily Dickenson Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Calling all Hydromorphone users DaughterMom marshakb

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2009 08:14PM DaughterMom wrote: Barbe, first I am glad it`s just a kidney stone.  Second, I am so sorry you have to wait so long for treatment.  You should move to Saskatchewan.  I spend alot of time in the ER lately with my mother, and after a while, I cannot help but be nosey and listen to the diagnoses and problems of other patients.  Doctors are sending patients to CT without batting an eye, one lady was dx with kidney stones and admitted, so that she could recieve a laser treatment in the coming days.  I guess our health care differs from province to province.  I lived in Toronto for a few years, but never had to deal with any health issues, thank goodness.  I hope you will get the care you need soon.  (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 11:57AM DaughterMom wrote: I am being brutally honest to myself in saying that I thought the same way, total ignorance.  Nobody understands until they walk a day in your shoes.  So sorry for the way that you and everyone else can sometimes be treated, people do say the wrong things, and they (we) should not speak unless we actually know what it is like.  I have since learned so much more over the the past 4 months, and I do agree that there needs to be a strong message sent out to the medical professions, and in general, a re-education of the facts of bc, especially stage iv.   Keep living your life!  and ignore us :)

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 08:52AM DaughterMom wrote: Just recently, there was a huge recall of the hard, usually coloured plastics, which contained toxins that leached into the product it contained.  There is also concern with the plastic coating used in tins and canned goods.  Very scary stuff.  I am very leery of plastics, and never use plastic in the microwave. Something has changed over the years when you really think about it.  Growing up, it was very rare to hear about Cancer, now it seems everyone knows someone who has cancer of some sort.

Posts.Content: DaughterMom wrote: Well, today I went to see a Dr about a small lump that I recently found in my left breast. Scared. I have been putting off this initial visit off since I found the lump a couple weeks before Christmas because of so many reasons. My mother has stage IV BC and we just found out in November'08. I am now staying with her during this ordeal, just looking after her. I have not told anyone about this lump that I found. When I phoned home and spoke to my husband, I had every intention to tell him, but I just couldn't. I don't want to instill any unnessessary fears in my family. The earliest mammo appt. we could get was FEB 4TH! (My mother lives in a smallish city) My Dr. decided to call the next nearest city (1.5 hr drive) and I have an appt. on January 14. This is the day before my mothers first appt with an Onc. at the Cancer Centre in the same city. I will have to somehow sneak away to my mammo appt. I don't want her to know, because she will worry too much. Scared. Hope is the thing with feathers, That perches in the soul, And sings the tune without the words, And never stops at all. -Emily Dickenson Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 01:45PM DaughterMom wrote: The wait is the hardest part.  I am praying that it is nothing, my Doctor mentioned that it could be a cyst, its just a round little ball, and he said he felt alot of tissue surrounding it, what ever that means.  I am hoping that his serious concerns where due to my history.  But what I have been reading on this forum is the mammo will just point out a mass, hello! I can feel it, it's there.  Then I will have to wait for a biopsy, and then another wait for results.  This is terrible.  But, just rambling, we all have to go through this wait, and wait somemore.   Thanks for listening.
Posts.Title: Went to Doctor today DaughterMom DaughterMom

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 04:28PM DaughterMom wrote: My mother was dx stage iv at age 60 (2 weeks before her 61st bday), this was Nov 2008. I am 39, found a lump, had mammo. and ultra sound in January, and now I am in the wait 6 months for another mamo. group.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 02:09PM DaughterMom wrote: My mother says her legs are weak, not sure exactly why, but I just assume that she is just plain tired.  I am interested to hear what others have to say about this.  This is the main reason why we moved to a new apartment this month, her old one had a huge flight of stairs to climb just to get to her apartment, so going out was a big deal.  She has a walker to help her steady herself, which she really likes, I don't think she would feel safe enough with a cane, but it may work for you.  As well, go ahead and apply for that sticker, anything that will make life easier for you while you regain your strength will help immensely.  I get the feeling that you may be upset because you feel that you have to resort to these measures, just try to look at it as making your world safer, and easier to manouver in. God Bless Oh, one other suggestion, get a great big cow bell, and ring it loud from the bottom of the stair to wake up your boys in the morning (unless they are still little, then they would be scared silly!)

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 09:58PM DaughterMom wrote: Luanne, that is hilarious!  Not the fact that you had to wait so long, but having your friend check your incision, right in front of the Doctor...I wonder what he was thinking.  I don't think he will forget, and hopefully got the point.  Good for you! I hate it when doctor's make patients wait.  My mother's GP always seems to be overbooked, to the point of ridiculous.  The last time we went to see her, I asked the nurse how long it would be, because mom cannot sit up for more than an hour, and she told me that there were four patients in front of her, and they were all getting full physicals. I asked if we could just sneak in between patients, because we just has a couple questions and needed a prescription refill, and promised that my sweet mother would not take too much of the doctor's precious time.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 05:57PM DaughterMom wrote: Yes, it is true Melissa.  It happened to me also.  Only 5 posts allowed in a 24hr period.  It was a bit frustrating, because I wanted to thank someone who responded to one of my threads...hmmm, I hope I remembered to post a thankyou.  I am playing the waiting game too.  I am 39 and my mother was just recently  dx with Stave IV bc, and I am her caregiver and support person during this time.  So much to deal with as it is, then a lump decides showed up one day.  Why!?  I just want to scream!  I had a mammogram and ultra sound on Wednesday. My Dr. should have the results today.  I am very curious about my BiRads rating.   I really am hoping this is just nothing...just a wait and watch type thing. I would be ok with that.  I have so much other things to worry about right now.   Melissa, I sure hope all is well with your biopsy.  Stay strong, you will get results soon.  Someone posted that a few weeks will not make a difference health wise, if god forbid it was malignant, BUT I understand that we have a justified NEED to know the status of our health.    Do you have any children?
Posts.Title: can somone help with posting question... MelissaA MelissaA

Posts.Content: May 17, 2009 03:17PM - edited May 17, 2009 03:22PM by DaughterMom My mother takes a 30mg time released dilaudid capsule twice a day.  Each pill slowly releases throughout the day/night for 12 hours.  She also takes a 6mg dilaudid tablet as needed for break out pain in between her slow release one, which works immediately.  The only side effects she experiences are constipation, but she also takes 3 senacot pillls a day, which helps.  She does get a bit sleepy after taking the inbetween pills, but she is still very lucid, maybe a bit wobbly on her legs, but it could be from overall weakness.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 07:40AM DaughterMom wrote: Janis , you have responded to a couple of my posts, and have always brought a smile to my face, thank you.  I have to agree that Journal writing does help because getting your feelings out in any form is very therapeutic.  I do that all the time, since my mom's dx I have enough pages in my word document 'Personal Notes & Feelings" to publish a book!  Get them out, and if you find that you disagree with yourself later, the delete button works great.  For my mother the small things in life bring a smile to her face, like an upcoming visit from her sister, or speaking on the phone to my 2yr old son.  He says things like "Bubba Boo-Boo?" or "I wuv you Bubba".  Real sweet, she always laughs.  Renee, You should not have to defend yourself for "Braving more treatment and managing the Ups and Downs."  Isn't that what this forum is about?  So pooh on anyone who feels like they have the right to judge you!

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 09:01PM DaughterMom wrote: Well, tomorrow is the day of the Mammo. in Saskatoon.   I am worried, but I am also optimistic that the lump is nothing, I hope. I will study the body language and facial expressions of the technicians like crazy.  I am a little stressed about this, because mom is currently in the hospital, she needed another blood transfusion. The Dr.'s understand the importance of her appt. at the Cancer Centre, so they will be releasing her tomorrow.  I am packing for our little excursion tomorrow,  and will pick her up at the hospital on the way out of town.  I told mom about my appt., but not about the lump.  She believes that I am just being precautious.  I just don't need her worrying about me, when she is so ill right now.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 12:13AM DaughterMom wrote: I had my mammo. yesterday and they also did an ultrasound around the lump. I was just shaking during the whole ordeal.  I swear to god, my heart was pounding so hard again the mammo machine that my whole body was moving with each heartbeat, I was thinking they would not get a clear scan, but it was probably just my imagination.  I don't know why, but I am all of a sudden getting very overwhelmed by all that is happening.  I am a strong person, why the heck am I crying?!  I haven't heard anything from my Dr. yet, but they said that they would send him the results within 24hrs.  I am calling the dr's office first thing.  I guess, the next step could possibly be a biopsy.  Madalyn:  The technicians where emotionless...other than kindly concern.  Couldn't "read" a thing from them! MTT66: I hope all goes well for you.  Thinking of you, please take care.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 08:40PM DaughterMom wrote: Just an update, Mom was admitted to the hospital on Monday!  Her doctor is not fooling around.  Mom is getting a Nephrostomy Tube inserted to both kidneys tomorrow morning.  Her blood tests show dangerously high numbers indicating kidney failure.  I love my mom so much, I just don't want to see her suffer.
Posts.Title: Mom agreed to Radiation treatments DaughterMom DaughterMom

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2009 02:06PM DaughterMom wrote: LuAnne, You are so inspirational, and a wealth of knowledge!  Thank-you, and I will look into the Xeloda for my mom.  Knowledge is Power. Mom had her first radiation treatment yesterday, and she is such a trooper!  She did so well, and is so brave.  I was a nervous wreck, but tried very hard to hide it.  The technicians sensed it, and let me watch on the monitors, and explained step by step what they were doing.   Immediately following radiation, she went to the Vascular dept. and had the Nephrostomy tubes inserted.  It was a tough day.
Posts.Title: Mom agreed to Radiation treatments DaughterMom DaughterMom

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 07:36PM DaughterMom wrote: Rose, We did meet with an Onc. as well, but my mother does not want to undergo any chem treatments.  the Onc. was very kind and respected her decision.  She told her doctors when she was dx, only two months ago, that she did not want any chemo.  I asked the Onc. if there was something else he could offer, but he said there is nothing.  I have a couple aunties that I can stay with during my moms hospital stay.  I can also come back to moms apt. as well, it is only an hour and 10 mins. drive if I need to.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2009 01:25PM DaughterMom wrote: Farrah's Story captured it all, the hope, the joy, the devastation and saddness, and the love and devotion.  I am glad I watched.  I loved that she danced the night away on her birthday, that was pure joy.  I cried when she was talking about the rain, and I smiled when she made the sign of the cross, with her rosary in her hand (my mother does that throughout the day), and her beautiful Ryan by her side through it all.
Posts.Title: Like a moth to a fire... Fitztwins bmdaley

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 10:14PM DaughterMom wrote: Oh sweetie, it is so hard to go through this at any age.  I am 39years old and my mother has bc, and it is taking a toll on me, I can only image how it is effecting you emotionally.  I have a teenage son, who is your age.  I can sense when he is upset and needs a hug or to talk, I usually wait for him to come to me, or I give him gentle little openings, and eventually he spills his guts to me.  I know your mother knows you are going through a tough time, and she will be theere for you, and will wipe your tears if you do cry.  She understands, just talk to her, tell her you love her and that you are scared.  You both will get through this together.  Take care, and post here often, it really does help to vent.
Posts.Title: my mom has breast cancer for the third time Kalah3Storm X3sMom

Posts.Content: DaughterMom wrote: My mother had her first appt. yesterday at the Cancer Centre in Saskatoon. The first doctor we met with was a radiologist and his RN.  They were amazing.  The first thing he wanted to be sure of was that mom really understood her diagnosis.  Which she does.  She has mets to her lung, liver and abdomen (not bone as I originally thought).  She also knows that the outcome of any threatment is for a better QOL.  The radiologist focused mostly on the mass that is causing her the most problems, her abdomen.  She has a blockage from her kidney and bladder, which is serious, she is starting to get swelling to her feet and now her arms and hands.  Mom agreed to allow the doctors to place a stint (stent?) in her urinary tract, and undergo 10 sessions of radiation treatments.  The treatments will start ASAP.  He will call us when we have to go back to Saskatoon.  Probably as early as next week.  My biggest relief is that the doctor decided that mom should be admitted to the hospital for the treatments.  This will make it easier for my mom and myself.  We don't have to worry about staying at the hostel (or what ever it is called, a home away from home for patients undergoing treatments) and traveling back and forth to the hospital everyday for two weeks.  I just pray that mom can somehow find the strength to endure this treatment.  I know that it will take a lot out of her, and she is so weak as it is.  But, in the long run, the risk of not getting this done now is far greater.  Today mom was saying that she is feeling really good about the upcoming treatment, and glad that she will be in the hospital.  She gets really good care in the hospital here in her hometown, so I am sure in a larger city, the care will be just as good.     Hope is the thing with feathers, That perches in the soul, And sings the tune without the words, And never stops at all. -Emily Dickenson Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Mom agreed to Radiation treatments DaughterMom DaughterMom
